Journalists and defense attorneys have so far taken on the sole responsibility for seeking records under #SB1421, and for bringing potentially tainted cases to the attention of prosecutors. This is unacceptable.

#SB1421 gave us a tool to root out police misconduct and ensure we can have confidence in our legal system’s outcomes. But law enforcement isn’t using this tool — and in some cases, it is working actively to undermine it.

When prosecutors build their cases around officers who have proven themselves untrustworthy or unreliable, it compromises the integrity of our entire legal system. Any conviction obtained in such a manner must be reviewed.

Initial disclosures have revealed that police officers with a history of misconduct — including sexual assault and dishonesty — are still on the job, and in some cases still providing testimony that is being used to determine guilt or innocence.

After baseball, Pumpsie Green worked at Berkeley High School for more than 20 years as a truant officer and coaching baseball and teaching math. In 2009, he was honored by the Red Sox on the 50th anniversary of when he broke the team’s color barrier.
But at his home debut at Fenway on Aug. 4, 1959, Pumpsie Green received a standing ovation from the Red Sox crowd. He promptly slammed a triple off the Green Monster, and the crowd went wild.

When Pumpsie Green joined the Red Sox, Black players were routinely denied the right to eat at restaurants and stay in hotels with white players. Green's dream was to one day play for his hometown team, the Oakland Oaks. He never got that chance.
Sixty years ago this summer, Pumpsie Green, became the first Black baseball player to play for the Boston Red Sox — the last team in the major leagues to integrate.
